review.title: Knowledge Representation in Learning Classifier Systems: A Review
review.abstract: Knowledge representation is a key component to the success of all rule based systems including learning classifier systems (LCSs). This component brings insight into how to partition the problem space what in turn seeks prominent role in generalization capacity of the system as a whole. Recently, knowledge representation component has received great deal of attention within data mining communities due to its impacts on rule based systems in terms of efficiency and efficacy. The current work is an attempt to find a comprehensive and yet elaborate view into the existing knowledge representation techniques in LCS domain in general and XCS in specific. To achieve the objectives, knowledge representation techniques are grouped into different categories based on the classification approach in which they are incorporated. In each category, the underlying rule representation schema and the format of classifier condition to support the corresponding representation are presented. Furthermore, a precise explanation on the way that each technique partitions the problem space along with the extensive experimental results is provided. To have an elaborated view on the functionality of each technique, a comparative analysis of existing techniques on some conventional problems is provided. We expect this survey to be of interest to the LCS researchers and practitioners since it provides a guideline for choosing a proper knowledge representation technique for a given problem and also opens up new streams of research on this topic.

metadata.title: Knowledge Representation in Learning Classifier Systems: A Survey

sections.text: ar Xiv: 150 6.04 002v 1 [cs.N E] 12 Juing learning classifier systems (LCSs) This component provides insights into the division of the problem area, which in turn aims to play a prominent role in the generalization capacity of the system as a whole. Lately, the knowledge representation component has received a lot of attention within data mining communities due to its impact on rules-based systems in terms of efficiency and effectiveness. Recent work is an attempt to find a comprehensive yet elaborate view of the existing knowledge representation techniques in the LCS domain in general and XCS in particular. To achieve the goals, knowledge representation techniques are grouped into different categories based on the classification approach in which they are integrated. In each category, the underlying rule representation scheme and the format of the classification condition are presented to support the representation. In addition, a precise explanation of the problem space is presented together with the extensive way of each technique and the results are presented.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The first framework of Learning Classifier System (LCS), labelled the "cognitive system," was introduced in 2004 by John H. Holland (Holand, 1976). LCSs were originally inspired by the general principles of Darwinian evolution and cognitive learning, and the LCS system was reformed to use reinforcement techniques such as Q-Learning (Sutton and Barto, 1998) to ensure adequate reward and propagation. LCS is also known as the rules-based evolutionary online learning system. It is a heuristic method in which a population of production systems exists and is adapted using genetic algorithms and reinforcement techniques of learning. Any production system can cover a small region of the environment and represent some parts of the overall solution. An LCS system is therefore able to solve a problem by using the best developed production systems in its popular era.

sections.heading: 3 Knowledge Representation
sections.text: In other words, the solution system must be able to model the regularities of the problem area in order to make decisions in relation to its experience. In rule-based systems, its rule set is the one responsible for such a modeling, where each rule represents a part of the problem area and makes the best decision in the corresponding subspace. Consequently, a rule-based system is able to solve a problem efficiently if the rule set can adequately cover the entire problem area, and also if each rule makes an effective decision in which each rule represents a part of the problem area and makes the best decision in the corresponding subspace. Knowledge representation, knowledge representation, representation in the dissemination of knowledge in the Learning Classifier System: A Survey 5has an essential role in rule-based systems. In particular, a rule-based classification such as XCS can achieve all three main objectives of the classification task, which are high accuracy, intelligibility and compactness, provided that there is proper rule-based representation.

sections.heading: 4 Relative Strength and Weakness of Knowledge Representation Techniques
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most of them are able to recognize and understand the problems they have. In this sense, it is also necessary that they get a grip on the problems they have in their entirety. In this area, we have a few simple problem solutions and analyze the relative strength and weakness of each of them. We look at the following categories of problems that we address.

sections.heading: 5 Summary and Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, we focus on the progress of XCS as a rules-based learning system, with particular emphasis on improving one of its most important components, knowledge representation. As this component seeks to play a prominent role in the generalization capacity of the system and has implications for rule-based systems in terms of efficiency and effectiveness, we have seen a growing interest over the last decade in proposing different knowledge representation techniques in the LCS domain in general and XCS in particular. Here, after reviewing some basic information, we collect various knowledge representation techniques proposed in the LCS field in Michigan and group them into different categories based on the classification approach in which they are incorporated. In each category, the underlying rule representation scheme and the format of the classification condition are presented to support the corresponding representation. In addition, a precise explanation can be given of how each technical knowledge represents representation in learning systems based on knowledge that serves as a guideline for other systems.
